div.p: 1. V:15. I began the morning of the New-Year, as I had the closing day of the last with writing to redeem the arrears of this Journal— Wrote a short Letter to Mr Joy, and sent back to him the Letters which he had enclosed to me for perusal. Began the draught of a Letter to Lord Castlereagh in reply to Lord Bathurst’s Note respecting the fisheries— It has long weighed heavily upon my mind, and perhaps ought not to have been delayed to this time. It must necessarily be long and my great concern will be to shorten it as much as possible without impairing the substance of the argument. In my walk before dinner I called at the house of Mr Gray to return his visit— He was gone to London, and I left a Card.— Mr J. A. Smith came out from town to dinner— He brought me two Letters— One from Mrs Eliza Giles, and the other from Mr Maury. Mrs Giles encloses an open Letter from herself, to The Treasurer of His Majesty’s Navy, Somerset House, London.— She gives in that Letter a statement of facts, respecting her Son, William Axtell Giles—namely, that in the year 1804, being an American, and a Gentleman by Birth and Education, he was impressed into the British Naval Service, and continued in it serving in various ships until 1809. when he was discharged as an American, having 17 Months pay, and prize money due to him.— That in 1813, he left New-York for Cadiz, and from the best information she has been able to collect (not having had any Letters from himself since that period) he again entered the British Navy, and sailed to Canada in the Linnet as Purser, and volunteered his services on deck during the action, wherein the Linnet was captured on Lake Champlain by Commodore M’Donogh—that she knows not how long he remained a Prisoner of War, but that he died suddenly and intestate at the Havanna on the 13th: of July 1815. That she has received all the necessary documents empowering her to receive from the British Government whatever was due from them to her son, and that some informalities have prevented her receiving it hitherto— She states her great want of the money, and solicits the immediate attention of the Treasurer of the Navy to this claim, and sends the Letter to me, desiring me to favour her with a line of recommendation, to facilitate the business; and wishes it to be put into the hands of Mr Beasley, the American Consul.— Mr Maury’s Letter still complains about the Sailors, and the want of money to assist them and pay for their passages. The Mayor of Liverpool has called upon him to see him and concert measures for sending home those who are become burthensome to the Parish—and Mr Maury having now upwards of 100 upon his hands, has resolved in future to afford relief only to the sick. Anticipating that this will occasion complaints against him in the United States, he writes to give me notice of it.— George made an attempt to resume his reading; but his cough made it difficult, and he read only two Chapters, and I the other four— The two eldest Nicholas’s, with an Italian young Lady, came and paid a morning visit to Mrs. Adams— They also spent the Evening here, and we all played at Loto, until past eleven.

2. VI. George, in addition to his cough is now afflicted with the rhumatism, and had this day considerable fever.— Mr Smith returned to town this Morning, after breakfast.— Mrs Adams had promised Mr and Mrs Hewlett that we would all go and dine with them in Town to-morrow. But being herself quite unwell, and George and Charles confined to the house, she wrote this day to apologize for us— I was employed all the morning after Breakfast upon my draught of a Note to Lord Castlereagh concerning the fisheries.— Walk to Hanwell and Ealing— A thick fog and frosty. Mr Grubb sent me out a pamphlet of a new invented Hydrostatic ship, or marine Mail Coach; which without fire, and almost without sails, is to go 14 Miles an hour against wind and tide, and in spite of storm or hurricane— Mrs: Adams had a Note from Mrs Michael Angelo Taylor, enquiring for the character of Ann Prudden— Mr Grubb wrote me also to inform me that Mr Bagot had called at the Office in Charles Street, and wished to see me, as he is going immediately to take his departure— Mr Grubb told him I would meet him to-morrow at N. 13. Craven Street, where he is to call about three. There was likewise a Christmas or New-Years visit from the Queen’s footmen, whom Mr Grubb referred to a future day.— This Evening, Mrs Adams began to read Miss Edgeworth’s Patronage.

3. VI: George’s Rhumatism, increases in severity, and this day he could scarcely use his hands. His cough however is less troublesome, and his breast has been partially relieved— Dr Cook was sent for to him again, and prescribed Pill, Powders and Potion for him— By the morning Post, I received a Packet from Mr J. A. Smith, containing Letters— 1. from himself, dated 31. Decr. mentioning a number of respectable characters at New-York, who had written to Washington, recommending him for the appointment of Secretary to this Legation, before he received my Letter of 22. July, and whose recommendations had alone prevented him from withdrawing his pretensions after he had received it— 2. From Mr Anthony Morris at Madrid, dated 18. Decr: in answer
to mine of 25. November last to him. It relates to the case of the William and Mary, upon which he says he made two applications in May last, to the Secretary of State Cevallos, from whom he received only a verbal, and very offensive reply in July that the case was under advisement. So that Mr Morris though his Letter is dated the same day that I received that from the Spanish Ambassador here, communicating the orders that he had received from his Court, to interpose for the restoration of the property, had not been informed that such orders had been given. 3. from Charles’s Cleland, in the New Prison—with thanks for the notice I had taken of his former Letter; and further solicitations, to obtain his release. 4. A Letter from Messrs: Ralph and Thomas Westropp of Limerick, to Coll: Aspinwall; soliciting the appointment of American Vice-Consuls at that Port— Mr Aspinwall had left the Letter at the Office to be forwarded to me— I was employed upon this Journal until breakfast—closed that last and began upon the present year; so nearly retrieving all arrears as to begin upon the narrative of yesterday, but not having time to finish it— Mr Huxley came and gave a lesson to John and Charles, but George’s hands are so stiffened that he could not take one— It was past twelve when I left home, and nearly two when I reached Mr Smith’s lodgings, Number 13. Craven-Street, where my Office is henceforth to be kept— Mr Grubb was there, with Mr Smith—And I found on the table Letters as follows. 1. From the Spanish Ambassador, Count Fernan-Nuñez, communicating a copy of Lord Castlereagh’s answer to his Note concerning the William and Mary, and informing me that he is ready to authorize Messrs: Dickason and Nevett to enter an appeal of Territory. 2. from Mr Jackson, our chargé d’affaires at Paris, with a bundle of Old Newspapers from the Department of State; brought to him by a Mr Sterry, appointed Consul at La Rochelle; and from Paris by Mr E. Morse. 3. From Mr Maury at Liverpool—Still concerning the Sailors and the want of money. 4. From Mr Bourne at Amsterdam, with complaints on the same Subject, and urging again compensation for Consuls. 5. From my Mother, with Letters from her to my three Sons, two other Letters for George, and a copy of my father’s Letter to Dr Price dated 19. April 1790 at New-York, a partial extract from which was published by Mr Morgan in his Memoirs of the Life of Dr Price— While I was at the Office, Mr John M. Aspinwall of New-York, brought me a Letter of introduction from his father Mr Gilbert Aspinwall one of the assignees of Robert Bird. He says in his Letter that he expects a dividend will soon be made— This young man is going immediately to Paris, and promised to take Letters for me, and the 200 franks which Lucy Hauel wishes to send for her father— He came for a Passport which was given him, and he asked, if he could not get Mr Grubb to obtain the endorsement of the French Ambassador, and the papers necessary from the Alien Office—and he added that Mr Grubb had done so for another American Gentleman, who had given him a fee for it; though Mr Grubb had told him there was nothing to pay for what was done at this Office— I told Mr Aspinwall, that Mr Grubb was no longer in this Office— That my strict injunction to him had been to take no fees whatever while in my Office; and that this was the first notice I had that he had ever taken any. He was indeed under no obligation to obtain for Americans the endorsement of the French Ambassador, or the papers at the alien-office, and he might have thought himself at Liberty to receive a fee for doing it— But had it been known to me I should strictly have forbidden it; and I could not permit that he should now receive a fee for doing any thing connected with the business of this office— Mr Aspinwall took therefore his Passport, to transact the business himself.— A Letter was likewise brought me from Mr Karthaus, in reply to mine of 23. December. Mr Bagot came about three—and informed me that the Frigate Niger was now ready, at Portsmouth and he expected to leave London next Saturday or Sunday to go and embark for Annapolis; though he should not move if the wind should be westerly. He offered again to take Letters, Despatches and any thing that I may wish to send— He said he was to have the same Captain, (Jackson) with whom he was to have gone out in the Lacedemonian— But that Frigate was a twin ship, with the Macedonian, they were both built for sailing, and so sharp, that there was not room for the stowage of his baggage. He had then taken a Transport to carry that— But the Niger was of a different Construction, and could take all his effects; so that he should take no Transport. As he said Lord Castlereagh, who is now at Norfolk, at Lord Suffield’s, the brother in Law of Lady Castlereagh, would be in town to attend next Monday at Brighton the celebration of the Princess Charlotte of Wales’s Birth-day, I asked him if there was any foundation for an insinuation lately twice repeated in the Morning Chronicle, that the Princess was to marry one of the Austrian Archdukes now here— He said none in the world— The Morning Chronicle had pretended that the late Council held at Brighton had been deeply engaged in that important affair. The truth was that the Council was held for the sole purpose of swearing in Lord Amherst—(The Ambassador going out to China) and there were so few members to attend it, that the Prince had been obliged to direct Mr Pole, to stay at Brighton a day longer than intended
because there were not sufficient number of the members present, to form a Council without him.— We had some further conversation, upon the late accounts from France— The escape of La Valetta—the projects of Amnesty and Revenge, the Ministry and the Legislative Chambers. I told him I should bring him some Letters for the United States on Friday. Mr Grubb had several times proposed to me, to subscribe to the Westminster Library N. 44. Jermyn Street; and having renewed this day the proposal, I assented to it— He informed the Secretary of my wish, and brought me a Catalogue of the Books, and a copy of the printed Terms of Subscription— He was then going into the City, and offered to call upon Messrs: Dickason and Nevett, whom I was desirous of informing of the substance of the Letter this morning received from the Spanish Ambassador. But before he left the Office, Mr Nevett came in— I shewed him the papers, and told him that they had now only to apply to Count Fernan Nuñez, who would immediately give them the authority to enter the appeal of Territory— Mr Nevett promised to send me some American Newspapers, arrived by the Milo; the vessel that brought the Letters from my Mother. Mr Chitty called, with the Broad Cloth, which I had ordered— Just before I left the Office, Mr Dashwood, one of Mr J. A. Smith’s fellow-passengers from New-York, came in— I thought I had seen him before, without recollecting where; and after some time, he asked me how I had been, since we came from Sweden together— I then immediately remembered him as the Purser of the John Adams— He gave a very bad account of Mr Jesse Nicholls who was also one of our fellow passengers from Sweden to the Texel— Mr Dashwood told us that he intended to go next Saturday to Liverpool, to embark immediately upon his return to America— He offered to take Letters— Mr Bagot, and Mr Pursh are to go about the same time— My Carriage was ordered at four, and came soon after. Mr Smith gave me several late American Newspapers and other publications.— I got out of the Carriage at the third and walked nearly to the sixth Mile-Stone— It was about six, when I reached home— In the Evening my wife read a few chapters of Patronage.

4. VI: Dr Cook says that the complaint in George’s breast is so far removed that it need give us no further uneasiness; but that he has an acute rhumatic fever, and must confine himself for several days to his bed chamber, and for the present to his bed. That it cannot be expected to terminate in less than twelve days, and may continue much longer— A fire was therefore made last Evening in his chamber, and he kept his bed the whole of this day— Antoine sleeps in the chamber with him— His mother was there almost the whole of this day. I was engaged from the time of rising, until four in the afternoon, with the exception of half an hour at breakfast, in writing—without however quite completing the Journal of Yesterday— My walk before dinner was short—only to Brentford and Ealing. I wrote Despatch N. 25. to the Secretary of State; and my wife wrote for me an answer to Mrs Giles— Received two Boston Newspapers from Mr Nevett; and a Letter from Mr G. Joy, enclosing one to him from Dr Kirkland, President of Harvard University—about the last years Westminster School Epilogue— Federalists at home and abroad, and the new Edition of Stephens’s Greek Thesaurus— In returning Mrs Giles’s Letter to the Treasurer of the Navy, I kept a copy of it— Mrs Adams read in the Evening some chapters of A Month in Town, a satirical novel upon certain characters in high life—full of scandal—probably more than of truth— I prepared a Packet for Mr J. A. Smith— The despatch to the Secy. of State— The Letter to Mrs Giles, with the enclosure—and the Note from Lord Castlereagh, concerning the Sailors— The Copies to be ready on Friday.

5. VI. The arrears of my Journal, are brought up to the present hour. I received last Evening a Letter from John Lee Millard, an American, as he states himself, and a convict, on board the Laurel Hulk, at Portsmouth—upon whose petition, I made an application to this Government, last October, without success— His Letter is dated 5. December, and renews the solicitation for my interference to obtain a pardon, or a commutation of his punishment— This morning I sent off the Packet prepared last Evening for Mr Smith; mistaking this day for Thursday— It was noon before I discovered my mistake, and then, too late to go in to Town— I wrote to Mr Jackson, the Chargé d’Affaires at Paris; a letter of introduction for Mr J. M. Aspinwall, and giving directions for the delivery to Mr R. Boyd, of the money, which Lucy sends for her father. I had just finished the Letter, when the Postman brought one from Mr J. A. Smith, mentioning that Mr Aspinwall had called yesterday to say that he should not go to France. There was also a polite Note from Coll Stapleton to Mrs Adams, and myself, mentioning that he was now about to embark for the United States, (he goes in the Frigate with Mr Bagot) and offering to take our Commands— The Newspapers, brought the Message of the President of the U.S. at the
opening of the Session of Congress, on the 5th. of December— Mr Joy also sent me out a Star of last Evening, containing it. I answered Mr Joy’s Letter, received last Evening, and sent him back, President Kirkland’s Letter to him— Wrote a Note to the Spanish Ambassador, acknowledging the receipt of his last Communications.— I had determined not to go this day to Town, principally for the sake of writing to my Father, by Mr Bagot— Began, but could not finish the Letter— It was past four when I walked out. George is still confined to his bed, by the Doctor’s orders— He was up only about an hour towards the Evening.— Mrs Adams received a Letter from her brother at New-Orleans. She was unwell this Evening, and could not read aloud.

6. V. I finished the Letter to my father before Breakfast. George was better, and able to sit up great part of the day; but not to leave his chamber. Dr Cook congratulated me upon the appearance of my eye, which is however yet very weak. I went to London, and found at the Office two Italians, subjects of the Pope, named Zanoni wishing to embark for the U.S One of them had a Passport from the Austrian Ambassador, already endorsed by Mr Grubb— The other, his brother had only a Passport from Mr Ragay, Secretary to the Dutch Ambassador, to go to the Low Countries, and wanted my endorsement upon it to obtain a Passport to go to America at the Alien-Office— I endorsed it— There was another person, applying for a Passport, for a Mr Rutherforth an American, now at Liverpool; his voucher, was a certificate from the Mayor of Falmouth given him upon his arrival in this Country— A Passport from Mr Bourke, the Danish Minister was soon after brought, to be endorsed. It was for a Mr Peterson, a Danish Subject, also now at Liverpool, going to America, but not suffered to depart for want of this Passport— I gave the Passport and the endorsement. I went to town principally for the sake of taking my packets of despatches and Papers to Mr Bagot; but his private Secretary Mr Hughes had been yesterday at the Office, and said he would probably not go this week.— Mr Pursh came in, and told me that the Nabby, the vessel in which he is to sail is already gone down to Gravesend, and that he should go there to-morrow Morning to embark. I gave the despatches and Letters to him— Mr Dashwood came to say that he should leave the City for Liverpool to-morrow Morning.— He is to go in the Minerva, the same vessel in which he and Mr J. A. Smith came—but will not sail in less than ten days or a fortnight— After I left home this morning I met the Postman, who stopped and gave me two Letters—one from Mr J. A. Smith, asking me to bring into town, Mr Beasley’s Letter of 9. Decr. to be copied, (but it was too late) and the other from Mr B. Price, Secretary to the Westminster Library, informing me that I had been proposed by Dr Andersen, and elected a Subscriber to that Institution.— I found at the Office a Letter from a Chevalier de Vaudoncourt, with one from Admiral Chichagoff, introducing him to me. This Gentleman is the author of the French pamphlet on the passage of the Beresina, which the Admiral gave me last Summer, with the English Translation of it, that he had published here— The Chevalier, who has already been two or three times at the Office, expresses an earnest desire to see me, and requests me to name a day for that purpose, either in the Country or in town.— I answered his Letter and appointed Tuesday next, between one and four O’Clock, to meet him at my Office in Craven Street— I enclosed in a Note to Coll: Stapleton, a packet which my wife had made up for her Sister, Mrs Buchanan, and sent it to his lodgings at the Barrack-Office, Spring-Garden.— He was out of Town, but is to return on Monday— Before I left the Office a Note was brought me from Lord Castlereagh—dated yesterday, and answering mine of 26. Decr: respecting the discrimination made between British and American Vessells, in the number of Passengers which they are permitted to take from Ireland— He says he finds no Article in the late Commercial Convention with which it is incompatible, and calls upon me to point out the expressions upon which I consider it to be so.— It was half past four when I quitted the Office, and past six when I got home— I walked from Kew Bridge, home— The mild weather has again thawed the roads, so that the walking is very bad— In the Evening, Mrs Adams read to me, several Chapters of Patronage— The Coachman went to Messer and Pages to change the harnesses.— This was the day of the Epiphany, or Manifestation of Christ to the Gentiles; commonly called Twelfth day.— Several of the Shops in Brentford were illuminated; particularly the Pastry Cook’s, with a great display of their goods for sale— One of them had at the bottom of the shop a Transparency, with Britannia pointing to the Inscription “Glorious Regency.” About a dozen of the rabblement were collected together before the door and staring at it.

7. VI. The night was clear, and this morning when I rose, besides the splendor of Venus and Jupiter, which I see from my windows whenever the morning Southern sky is unclouded, I had a view of many other Stars, which I did not recognize. The
Journal of yesterday was completed. George was not so well this day as yesterday. At Breakfast I received a Letter from Mr G. Joy— With extracts of his own Letter to Dr Kirkland, the answer to which he had sent me before. He likewise suggests a question, whether the situation in which we reside is not an unhealthy one— I attended Church with my sons John and Charles. Mr Carr read Prayers for the first Sunday after the Epiphany. Dr Bond preached the Sermon. Psalm XC.12. So teach us to number our days, that we may apply our hearts unto wisdom. It was an occasional discourse, upon the commencement of the New-Year— Dr Bond is a preacher certainly above the ordinary Class, and he has the faculty of fixing the attention of the hearer. But I was not so much pleased with his Sermon of this day, as with the last, and am suspicious that his principal merit is an elegant Style; with an ambitious delivery.— He married a couple, immediately after the reading of the Second Lesson. This Ceremony, which I had never before, seen performed in Church on a Sunday, lengthend the Service nearly half an hour, though Dr Bond omitted all the latter part of the marriage service.— The whole leisure of the day I employed in preparing a Note to Lord Castlereagh, in reply to that which I received yesterday from him— Shortened by walk before dinner the roads being yet bad; and the Evening was idle.

8. V: A day of miscellaneous occupation, in which with twelve hours of employment, I did a little of many things. The Journal was short; I wrote an answer to the Letter of Millard, the convict at Gosport, a despatch N. 26. to the Secretary of State; to be sent by Mr Bagot, and began a Letter to my Mother.— As I am now enabled to write again with my own hand, though slowly and with difficulty, I resort again to the copying-Press, from which I take copies of my Letters and despatches, which although often faint, and scarcely legible, are at least the most accurate of all copies when they can be read— My Letter Books, are all so incorrect that I scarcely ever have occasion to recur to the copy of a Letter in any one of them, without detecting several errors—sometimes omissions of a whole sentence—often of a whole line—often the whole interval between the recurrence twice of the same word, and often mistakes of words, which distort the sense of a paragraph into nonsense or absurdity— The omission of the word “not” often inverts the meaning of a sentence, and turns denial into affirmation— These errors are inseparable from all copying, and increase in numbers when the writing of one person is copied by another. Long practice, gives a copying Clerk more or less of accuracy, according to his proportion of Understanding and assiduity, but none can ever be perfect.— The Press-Copy if legible, is always a perfect transcript from the original.— I took copies of my Note to Lord Castlereagh, and of my despatch to the Secretaty of State. Mrs Adams made me a Copy of the Note— I made out my quarterly Account to be transmitted with the despatch— A walk before dinner to Brentford and Ealing— Drizzling rain and foul roads— Received a Note from J. A. Smith, with information that he has six Packets for me from the Department of State, brought by Mr Price of New-York, and that he keeps them until to-morrow. Also a Letter from Mr Grubb, at N. 11. Threadneedle Street, the Consular Office. He encloses to me three Letters—from my father, my mother and A. H. Everett, dated 10 and 11. March last. Grubb says the Master of the New-England Coffee-House found them with some Newspapers in a drawer of his Predecessor— They had been brought by Mr De Grand’s Clerk, E. Copeland whom I saw in Paris last April. By what accident they came into the possession of the Master of the Coffee House, it is useless to enquire; but in his drawer they must have lain these nine Months.— Mr Smith likewise sent me out the Examiner of Yesterday; a Sunday’s paper; and an anonymous Note, from one of the tribe of inventors, who wishes to know what encouragements or rewards are given in Am—a to a man who should invent a New System of defence in Batteries— So that nobody, or next to nobody should be exposed to be killed.— Mrs Adams read about an hour in Patronage, after Dinner— George, whose rhumatism and cough are better has now a complaint in his legs, which the Doctor thinks an Erysipelas. He cannot yet leave his chamber.

9. V:30. Finished the Letter to my Mother, and took it, with the Note to Lord Castlereagh, and the despatch N. 26 into London. John and Charles went with me. I found at the Office the Chevalier de Vaudoncourt, who had been recommended to me by Admiral Chichagoff; he told me that having been an Officer in the French army, and having written an impartial History of the Campaign of 1812. he had not felt himself easy in France, under her present situation. He had therefore withdrawn from that Country, and had been obliged to leave his property behind; not having been able to dispose of any part of it— That he was desirous of going to America, the only Country where the principles to which he was devoted
were yet in honour, and he wished to know whether in his profession as an Officer of Artillery he could expect employment, or assistance in any other manner from the Government of the United States— I told him of the great difficulty which there must be, under the present Circumstances for any foreign Officer to obtain military employment in America, from the great embarrassment of the Government to provide for the meritorious native Officers, who have been in the service during the War; many of whom they had just now been compelled to discharge— He said he was aware of that, but there were great numbers of other persons in France situated like himself— Some had already gone to America; and he particularly mentioned the two Generals Gilly— Many others would be going as they should find opportunities. He had thought there might be enough of them to form a Colony, while Peace should continue, and that perhaps the Government might be disposed to give them some assistance. I told him that I believed whatever could be done in that way, must be effected by the means of individual and voluntary association— If numbers adequate to the formation of a Colony could associate themselves together, and undertake a settlement, the Government might afford them some facilities with regard to the acquisition of Lands, as had been done in similar cases, but that was all that could be expected— He asked me, if he could easily find opportunities to embark for the United States, in an American Vessel; for he should not like to go in any other— I told him there were American Vessels continually going from Liverpool, and others, though not so often, from London— He would find no difficulty in obtaining a Passage, by any of them, and I would render him any service in my power, that could be necessary to assist him. He promised to call upon me again; and to lend me a copy of his History of the campaign of 1812 to read— It was an enlargement of the pamphlet upon the passage of the Beresina, which Admiral Chichagoff gave me last Summer— He would give me a copy of the work; but he had not yet been able to publish it— He had left an Edition of it, printed at Paris, but so harsh was the tyranny exercised over the Press in that Country, and such inquisitorial searches had been making for his book, that his Printer had been obliged to send the whole Edition from his own house, and out of Paris to a place where it could be hidden— The persecution of every body who had belonged to the French army was equally rigorous— There was a system of proscription pursued against them— He had written Letters lately to several General Officers at Paris, and among them to one who had been a warm partizan of the Bourbons, the person to whom he had sent the Letters to deliver them, and to whom he had indicated the places of their lodging, had answered him that he had called at those places, but none of those persons were to be found; and added some obscure and singular expressions, from which he could only infer that they had all been arrested—and he had heard from another quarter that eighteen or twenty Generals had been arrested at once— He spoke of Marmont as an infamous character who had betrayed his Country; but said he had acted lately a generous part in the case of Ney, and of La Valette— He expressed high admiration at the heroic devotion of La Valette’s wife but said if the Duchess d’Angoulême could have her will, Madame La Valette would be guillotined instead of her husband— Marmont’s first intercession for La Valette, he said had been that the mode of his Execution might be changed— He had wished to die the death of a Soldier— But the king had answered that the Law must have its course— He had no power to alter it.— The Chevalier also told me that General Sebastiani was now in London— He too had been obliged to leave all his property behind him— He had not been able to sell even the furniture of his lodgings— Mr: Vaudoncourt said he knew not how long this state of things would continue in France—the Emperor Napoleon had organized an internal Government so energetic, that the Bourbons now in possession of all the means provided by him, might maintain themselves against all possible resistance— The immense majority of the population of France, was against them— Not one hundredth part of the People was in their favour; but the one might long tyrannize over the ninety nine.— At all Events, if a change should take place, and there should be any thing to be done in France, he should immediately return there— The Chevalier now left me, and I took up the six packets of despatches from the Secretary of State. I had expected that some of them would be merely packages of Newspapers and U.S. Laws— But they were all written, and so voluminous, that before leaving Town, I could read only a very small portion of them. There are Letters from Mr Monroe of the 16th. 19th. 20th. 23d: (two) and 28th: November, with a great mass of documents enclosed; concerning the Negroes, Indians &c— A Letter from the President of the United States, to the Grand-Duke of Tuscany, in answer to one which I transmitted last Summer— Two despatches for Mr Eustis at the Hague, which I left with Mr Smith to be sent by Mr Glover who is going for Holland next Monday— And two private Letters to me, one from Mr Plumer of New-Hampshire; and one from a Mr Benjamin Galloway of Hagar’s Town Maryland; requesting me to make enquiries concerning a certain Mr William Pulteney Dana, a kinsman of the late Sir William Pulteney, and father of a very interesting
young Lady, eleven years of age, Miss Ann Dana, living in the State of New-York. There was also a Letter from Mr Harris, at St Petersburg, dated 9. December. I sent Richard to Mr Bagot’s house to enquire whether he was gone, and if not, when he should go— He is not gone, and intends to go, with the first easterly wind— Mr: Laurence Prytz a Swede going to America, came with a Passport from Baron Rehausen, the Swedish Minister, which I endorsed. Mr Pursh came, to take leave again; and is going down to Gravesend this Night or to-morrow morning— His money had run short again, and I lent him £5 more, taking his Note in duplicates— He promised to repay the whole immediately after his arrival at New-York— Mr Smith made out a fair copy of my Note to Lord Castlereagh, which I signed, and took with me— The duplicates of the despatches 24. and 25 to the Secretary of State were made up, and I took them with the packet of Newspapers, and the Letter addressed to my father.— I left them at Mr Bagot’s House N. 41. Upper-Brook Street, with a Card, and told his Servant that there would come for him another packet this Evening, by the two-penny Post. Mr Smith was making the Copy of Lord Castlereagh’s note of the 5th: to me, to enclose it, with my answer, and my despatch N. 26— I stopp’d on the way, at Lord Castlereagh’s house, in St. James’s Street— Left the Note for him and enquired if he was in town— He is at Brighton, to celebrate with the Prince Regent, the Princess Charlotte of Wales’s birth-day. It was past five when I left the Office, and about seven when we got home— I was not able to read this evening the whole budget of documents that came with the despatches.— Mrs Adams finished in the Evening the first Volume of Patronage. George is better, but cannot yet leave his chamber.

10. V—45. Received by this Morning’s Post, a Letter from Coll: Aspinwall the Consul, informing me that he has contracted for the passage of 120 destitute American Seaman, at £ Sterling a man; and has engaged himself to pay the money immediately upon the departure of the Vessel from Gravesend— He therefore calls upon me for an order upon the Barings for £1200. I was engaged until breakfast with my Journal, and after it, until 4. O’clock, upon the draft of the Note to Lord Castlereagh, upon the fisheries— Walked to the Turnpike on the Windsor road— Began reading the documents that came with the despatches from the Secretary of State. The Evening Post brought a Note from Mr Grubb, with a Boston Centinel of 6. December.— Barren— Mrs Adams had a sore throat, and could not read aloud— I therefore answered Coll: Aspinwalls Letter; enclosed to him the order which he requested, upon the Baring’s, took a copy of both, and wrote a Letter to Mr Jackson, our Chargé d’Affaires at Paris, to go by Mr John C. Gray, who intends to go next week to France.— George is still confined.

11. V:15. After the Journal wrote Letters before Breakfast to Mr John Meulemeester, and Mr Van Huffel the Painter, of Ghent, to be sent by Mr Gray— Began one in answer to that which I received at Paris from Mr Cornelissen last March. Sent the Letter enclosing the Order on Messrs: Baring to Coll: Aspinwall. After Breakfast I continued writing upon the draft of a reply to Lord Bathurst’s Note on the Fisheries— Mr Bates the House Agent came, and I settled with him for the Rent of the house in which we live, up to the second of this Month, when the term of the first written agreement expired. It has since been agreed between Miss Clitherow and myself that we are to keep the house, at five guineas a week, and to give on either side a Month’s Notice at quitting. I enquired of Bates, whether he had now any houses on hand, in Town, or in the neighbourhood, to let— He mentioned several; but he says the Rents of well situated houses have not fallen at all— Secondary situations will not fetch so much as they did two years ago— It is almost impossible to sell any real Estates; the sales that he has made are not so great by many thousands as they were last year—and the case is the same with others; for he has been informed that the auction duty has not yielded this year one half the sum that it did the last.— What the sum that it yielded was, he does not know— But they have let as many houses as before. He is to send me a Note of the houses they have, to let on lease by the year— I walked to Gunnersbury and Brentford, and the Evening was employed in reading through the Documents received with the despatches from the Secretary of State— They relate to the demands on our side for the restoration of Slaves—to the imputation upon the British of having sold Slaves taken in the United States; and a second copy of the papers in the case of Mr Downman— Also the Correspondence between Coll: Hawkins, the Agent of the United States with the Creek Nation, and the British Coll: Nicolls— These last papers should have been sent me with a former despatch— A new task is imposed upon me by these despatches, the importance of which must be duly weighed. George left his chamber first this day, and was two or three hours in the adjoining Drawing chamber.

12. VI. My rising hour should be five— But on our firm resolves, the inaudible and noiseless foot of Time, steals on. More than half the Morning’s find me yet in bed at or near six. It was thus this morning, and I lost thereby the moments for finishing the Letter to Mr Cornelissen. I wrote however a short Letter to Mr R. Boyd, to send with the ten Napoleons for Lucy Hauel’s father, by Mr J. C. Gray; and went into London. It was past twelve O’Clock when I left my door, and just before I stepped into the Carriage the Postman brought me a Letter from Mr Hughes of Baltimore, enclosing one for Mr Russell at Stockholm— A Letter from a Mrs Wiltshire requesting to see me, and calling herself an American; and a Packet from Count de Beroldingen, the Minister of the King of Wurtemberg enclosing two papers of enquiries, concerning property of individuals in North and South Carolina, natives of Wurtemberg— I took these papers with me—the Coachman took me, by the Uxbridge road, half a mile shorter than that by Brentford, Hammersmith and Kensington, but at least now two miles heavier I first went to the Counting House, of the Brothers, Baring and Co. and saw Mr Alexander Baring. I enquired if the remittance of 25000 dollars, from the Treasury Department, which the Secretary of State had informed them, would be made, and upon which he had given me a credit upon their house, to that amount, had been made— He found it had not; but said they had an old balance due to the United States upon the diplomatic fund, and I might therefore draw without reserve— I took a draft for £1500 and signed triplicate receipts for it— Mr Baring mentioned that their usage had been to keep a private account with the Minister of the United States, crediting them for their quarterly Salaries, and then debiting them with the monies paid them. I told him that was the proper course, when the credits given to the Ministers by the Department of State, were as I presumed they had been, and as mine had been, while in Russia, upon the Bankers of the United States at Amsterdam, for an annual sum, the amount of their Salary and the Contingencies of the Legation— But my credit upon them was for a specific sum—25000 dollars— I could draw upon them only to that amount, and might draw for it all at once, or as suited my convenience— I had other accounts open with the Government, and a balance due to me for former expences— Mr Baring assented to these remarks, and gave me a draft on Martin Stone and Martin, Bankers, 68 Lombard Street for the £1500— We had then some conversation upon general topics— I mentioned the approaching Session of Parliament— He said it would pass off in perfect quietness. There was no Opposition— The Ministers were firm as Rocks. I asked him whether something would not be said about the distress of the agricultural interest, of which we occasionally heard. How the revenue would stand, and whether they could give up the property tax— He said, laughing, that the agricultural interest was to be sure in a sad State; but the Revenue of the year, would exceed that of the last— There had been however a falling off in the last Quarter— Not of the Excise, but of the Customs.— As to the property tax, poor Vansittart was like the man with his wife, nec possum tecum vivere nec sinete—there was a clamour against the tax which made it almost impossible for him to renew it; and yet he could not well do without it— He, Baring had been writing him a Letter yesterday, and proposed to him to take it off from the tenants—to leave it on the Landlords, and on the funds reducing it to five per Cent— This would yield about six Millions— He would take six Millions more from the sinking fund, and five Millions from what were called the War taxes— This would form an establishment of about seventeen Millions. More could not be necessary— There never was a period when a small peace establishment could have been more safe and easy than at this time. Never a period when the Country was in such perfect security— The army was for some years to be maintained by France; there was no danger to be discerned from any quarter, and (laughing) your Navy (said he) is the only one now formidable to us—and more formidable than all the naval power in the world, beside— Seventeen Millions a year therefore would be sufficient for the Peace Establishment, and the ordinary revenue of the Country would be just sufficient to pay the interest of the debt. As to the sinking fund—the forms must be observed—it was to be left untouched in point of form, but loans of about six Millions every year must be made, which would intrench so much upon it. For the last twenty years this Country had been borrowing, upon an average twenty-five Millions every year— This of course had been collected from the savings of the People— If now from a borrower, the Country should suddenly become a lender, to the amount of eleven millions a year, it would throw back upon the People, a Mass of Capital, without employment, the effect of which must be to reduce the rate of interest— It would be, as he had known it in Holland, where he had seen Stocks, bearing an interest of two and a half per Cent, above par— He would leave about five Millions of the sinking fund still to operate, which would be as much as it could without inconvenience. But he supposed we should hear a great deal in Parliament about economy, (laughing) retrenchments and the like— The Ministry he said were very good sort of people, and
quite pacific in their disposition— Lord Liverpool was a very worthy, amiable man— So was Lord Sidmouth— There was but one very warlike man among them, and that was Lord Bathurst— It was entirely upon his suggestion that the Troops from Spain had been sent over to Canada. The Expedition to New-Orleans had been entirely a plan of his.— I said that the disposition, upon both sides seemed at present so pacific that I hoped we should have a long, and quiet Peace— I was sorry however to hear that they were increasing their armaments on the lakes of Canada; because arming on one side would make it of course necessary to arm on the other; and we had been disposed on the contrary to disarm there altogether— He said their arming was the foolishest thing in the world—for, said he we are “the lamb” in Canada; it is in vain for us to think of growing strong there in the same proportion as America— [“]But surely our Ministers will consent to disarm there on both sides”— I said they had always a sufficient security against a sudden attack upon Canada, by the exposed state of our Commerce— He replied that he wished the British Government would give us Canada, at once— It was not worth Sir James Yeo’s hundred gun ship, and was fit for nothing but to breed quarrels. I mentioned to him the series of Articles in the Morning Chronicle, against the late commercial Convention, and after speaking of their character and tendency, and of the perverse ability with which they were written, said I was a little surprized at the quarter from which they came.— He had not seen the Papers; but from the description that I gave of them he thought he knew whence they came— That Perry (Editor of the Morning Chronicle) had formerly been under controul; but now he was under none, and his main object doubtless was to worry the Ministers— He said he would collect the Papers and read them— On leaving Mr Baring I went to Mr S. Williams N. 13. Finsbury Square Enquired the state of my Account with him, gave him the draft for £1500. and took a draft from him on Stephenson, Remington and Smith, 69. Lombard Street, for £500— I shewed him the Letter that I lately received from Mr G. Ludlow, at New-York, and asked him to procure the power to receive the October dividend— I enquired the present price of American six per Cent Stocks— He said there were no Sellers; but 83 1/2 had been offered, for them yesterday— Mr Baring had told me the same thing. Baring added that his house had received Letters from the United States, from various quarters at the same time; to buy for them and hold the Stocks— On the calculation that they would rise— He said they probably would rise— But he thought the exchange upon this Country would rise too— That it would be at a considerable advance even for specie. American goods here were very flat— Cottons would fetch scarcely any price at-all— Tobacco had sold very well, but there was none. The exports from this Country to America, had very largely exceeded the imports— The American Market was indeed now very fully supplied, and the demands had in a great measure ceased— Mr Williams too, doubted whether the American Stocks would rise much— He said the french Stocks now yielded eight per Cent— But French Stocks are funded upon a Volcano— I asked Mr Williams if he knew any thing of a Mr Nickels, who some time since borrowed of me a document a Judicial opinion of Judge Davis of Boston; and has not returned it— He said he had seen him about ten days since, but knew not where he lodged, or where he was to be found. He had failed in the application for the restoration of his vessel, but had been informed, that he might perhaps obtain the half, that came as a droit of Admiralty to the Crown— Mr Williams gave me some Papers of a similar case, the ship General Gates, captured 26. May 1812. under the orders in Council. The Trial suspended, being detained subsequent to the 20th. of May; but condemned to the Captor, 4. Novr: 1812 in consequence of the War. Mr Williams said he put these papers into my hands as he had been requested; though he had no expectation that any thing could be done for the owners, and had written so to them. He told me that he had sent to my Office in Craven Street, some Letters for me, which had been brought by Mr Tarbell. I called at Lackington’s to enquire for Chalmers’s Political Annals of the Colonies, and Adair’s History of the Indians, which Mr Plumer had written to request me to procure for him; but they had neither of the Books— Went to the Bankers N. 69. Lombard Street, and took up Mr Williams’s draft, that is, the money upon it. Thence proceeded to the Office in Craven Street. It was five O’Clock when I arrived there I sent the Carriage, to put up the horses at their owner’s, for an hour, and walked there, at the expiration of the time.— Mr Smith had sent from the Office, to the three penny Post-Office, a Note from Lord Castlereagh. While I was there the Letters brought by Mr Tarbell and which Mr Williams had sent me, arrived— They were from my father, mother and brother, to myself and to all the family. Mrs Wiltshire had been at the Office— Her object was to beg or borrow— Mr Smith gave me also some papers left by a Mr
Fead— A grant of Lands in West-Florida, on the Alibama river was made to his father, by the king in 1770.— The grant was deposited and registered in the American Consular Office in 1805. and Mr Lyman, then the Consul gave a certified copy of it, which is the paper now produced; and with it is the copy of a plot of the land, surveyed and set off to Fead in 1769. He is now dead, and his Son applies to know if he can have the Land. I took the papers with me, to see if I could find any thing on the Subject in the U.S. Laws— Walked in the Rain from the Office to Clarke’s Stables— It was near eight in the Evening when I reached home— George continues convalescent— Mr Frank Nicholas had been here— His father is to be at home to-morrow Morning.

13. V: I left last Evening with Mr Smith, the Letters that I had prepared to send by Mr J. C. Gray, and the 200 franks, from Lucy, for her father.— This morning, I could not finish before Breakfast the journal for yesterday. Received the Note from Lord Castlereagh. It is a requisition to me, to take measures for sending home 26 Americans, represented by the Mayor of Liverpool, as being now supported by the Overseers of the Poor of that Town— Lord Castlereagh has not yet replied to my Note concerning the Representation from the Lord Mayor of London— I finished my first draft of a reply to Lord Bathurst’s Note upon the fisheries.— Walk to Brentford; and then to Laws’s tavern to the Club dinner. There were only Dr Nicholas, who got home this morning; Mr Gray and Mr Copland. Major Morison, upon whom Mr Copland had called on his way from Town, to take him with him, had forgotten the club dinner, of this day, and had dined at home. Von Harten did not appear; nor any other of the Gentlemen who had been expected. We made no agreement to meet again, but had a social and not unpleasant dinner— No Politics— Dr Nicholas talked about his welsh tour. He said no body paid any rents in Wales at present. He had £300 due to himself for Rent for an Estate in Wales; of which he could not obtain a farthing. They spoke of Dr Bond rather slightingly, for scolding in the Pulpit, at his auditors, for not having their Servants to attend family prayers— I asked if family prayers were customary in this Country— They said they were practiced in the Evening by four families out of five, in the Evening; and sometimes in the midst of a Card party; they call in the Servants; leave the table hurry over the prayers, and sit down to Cards again till 3 or 4 in the Morning.— We parted about ten O’Clock.

14. VI: The journal employed me until the breakfast hour— Mrs: Adams is unwell, and was not with us at breakfast, yesterday or this Morning. I attended Church with John and Charles— Mr Carr read prayers— The Sermon was by Mr Milman, a new comer, a very young Man, son of Sir Henry Milman, and just entering upon his Career. It was his very first performance. The Sermon was very short— The text Psalm XIV.1. The fool hath said in his heart, there is no God— With many marks of youth in the composition, there was good sense, reasoning, and eloquence, the promise of future merit— The delivery was bad, both in pronunciation and in Action. a canting utterance—a stiff and aukward continual shake of the head; and utter ignorance of the modulation of the voice— Mr Carr gave notice that next day Thursday was appointed as a day of Thanksgiving for the termination of the War against France.— I was precluded from my walk before dinner, by the rain. Wrote two Letters to Mr Maury; and a Note to Lord Castlereagh, requesting an interview with him; to be sent into town to-morrow. I see by the Sunday’s Observer of this day, that Anthony M’Kenrot, the man who has twice written me strange Letters, and who was indicted for a forgery, has been acquitted at the old Bailey, by a verdict finding him not guilty, on the ground of insanity. George is still recovering, and this day first dined with us, since his confinement.

15. V:15. Coachman went into Town. I sent by him the Note to Lord Castlereagh, and papers to Mr Smith to be copied. I directed him also, to call at Mr Bagot’s house, and enquire if he was gone. There was a continual storm of rain, the whole day, so that I was confined to the house, and lost my customary exercise of walking. I was employed in making out from the first draught, a Note to Lord Castlereagh on the fisheries— How much to alter! how much to strike out! how much to add!— My progress is slower with the fair copy than it was with the first draught— The Coachman brought me a line from Mr Smith, saying that nothing had been received from Lord Castlereagh this day. His Servants told the Coachman that he was gone out of town for a week, but that my note would be sent to him tomorrow. Mr Bagot is not yet gone— Still waiting for a change of wind.

16. V:30. The journal for yesterday was so barren, that I neglected writing it this Morning, and resumed the fishery Note. But the further I advance in it, the more dissatisfied I am with what I have done— There is in the Note to which I reply much groundless assertion, and much erroneous principle, not bearing directly upon the point in controversy— I have in my first draft wasted argument in reply to these untenable positions— Effacez souvent—is the advice of Boileau to the Poets— It is very good advice for me; but I am not sure of my own judgment in acting upon it— I advanced only one page in my new copy. I wrote a
Note to the Prince of Esterhazy the Austrian Ambassador, enclosing with it, the Letter from the President of the United-States, to the Grand-Duke of Tuscany. Went in to London, and took my Sons John and Charles with me.— At the Office I had a long visit from Mr G. Joy— Mr Albert Chrystie, a young man from New-York, delivered me a Letter of Introduction from Mr Gallatin, to whose family he is related. It is dated 9. December. He says Mr Gallatin has declined the mission to France— Mr Chrystie lodges in the house N. 13. Craven Street, and proposes going next week for France— There came two women; one of them with a child perhaps two years old. She brought a letter to me, from Mr Birnie, a Bow-Street Magistrate, recommending her to me, as an American woman, who had been deceived and married at Halifax, to a man who had brought her here; where he had already another wife and Children.— And he is now in prison upon a charge of felony. She wanted to return to America, but as she belonged to Halifax I sent her back to Mr Birnie, advising her to ask him to recommend her to Lord Bathurst, the Minister for the Colonial Department— She said the name of the man who had pretended to marry her, was Thomas Laymore— That he had been Captain’s Steward of a merchant vessel, and here a waiter at an Inn. The woman who came with her said that she was now living with her; but totally destitute of all means of support— She herself was the wife only of a labouring man, and could not maintain her long.— I went to Williams the Stationers at the corner of the Street for some Articles, of his shop— John and Charles had left me at Hyde-Park Corner, and went to pay a visit to Mr and Mrs Mills in Harley Street. They came to the Office, just as the Carriage came— I called at Mr Bagot’s, and left a packet of Newspapers for the Secretary of State, with Letters for my father and Mrs Buchanan, and one from Mr Joy to the President.— Then at Prince Esterhazy, the Austrian Ambassador’s— He was not in town, but is to return to-morrow. I left the Note, with the Letter to the Grand-Duke of Tuscany, to be given to him— On the return home I walked from Brentford.

17. V:30. Received at breakfast this morning a Note from the Prussian Minister, Baron Jacobi-Kloest, requesting me to obtain authentic information concerning a native of Berlin, named Czeyka, who died at Hagarstown in the State of Maryland, in the year 1813— One Braun has written to the Chief Consistory at Berlin, that Czeyka, who had a wife, but no children in America, and who died leaving an Estate of about 4000 dollars, did upon his death-bed declare to him, Braun, that he had a wife and children living at Berlin, who were to be the heirs of his property. The American wife had a daughter, by a former husband, whose Son, named Drawinger took possession of Czeyka’s Estate at his decease; but upon Braun’s oath to the above Circumstances it was placed under the Care of the Orphan’s Court at Hagarstown to await the Claims of the lawful heirs— Braun writes from Philadelphia, asks for a Power of Attorney from the heirs to receive the money, which he offers to remit to a house at Altena; claiming a portion himself as joint-legatee, which he says Czeyka promised him as a reward for this service— Upon the enquiries made at Berlin, collateral relations of Czeyka have been found, but no traces of a wife or Children— And I am requested to obtain authentic information from America, to ascertain whether the relations at Berlin have any claim to the Estate— I was immersed all day, deep in the fisheries— Mr Mares one of the Masters at Dr Nicholas’s School, who teaches Greek and Latin called upon me. He had given private Lessons to George during part of the last Term, and was to have given them at his house, to the three boys during the vacation— But he has been absent until this day— And now, George is so unwell that he will probably not be able to resume his Studies before the Commencement of the next Term at School, and the Vacation is so far advanced that I did not think it worth while to send the other two boys to Mr Mares— I told him however I should wish him to give private lessons again to George, when he returns to School. I walked through Brentford to the Windsor Turnpike— While at dinner Mrs Adams received a Letter, from her Sister, Mrs Smith, at New-York; and I had one from Mr Gulian Ludlow of the same place. Both dated 11 Decr. and both marked Ship-Letter-Gravesend— The Letter from Mr Ludlow was upon business and enclosed a Bill of Exchange upon Minets and Stride, for £58:11:9.— In the Evening, Charles was reading in Mrs Hannah More’s Sacred Dramas, which I have given him. George rode out this morning—the first time since his confinement. [symbols]

18. V:15. Without neglecting the journal again this morning, I was plunged all the rest of the day in the fisheries; and nearly finished my note on that subject. My wife is making a copy of it at the same time. Received by the morning Post, a Note from the foreign Office, in Lord Castlereagh’s name, appointing the 25th. instant at half past eleven, to see me, and apologising for the delay, from his being in the meantime detained in the Country. By the Evening Post I had a Letter
from Mr Maury at Liverpool, and one from Mr G. Ludlow at New-York.— The latter a duplicate of that received last Evening; with a Postscript of 20. December. Mr Maury says he has received three Packets for me from New-York, and sent them by the Mail Coach, directed to N. 25. Charles Street.— The Packet has arrived at Falmouth in twenty days from New-York and the Morning Chronicle of this day has the commercial Convention, which we signed on the 3d. of July last, with the President’s Ratification; under the exception relative to the Island of St Helena, which was notified by Mr Baker the Chargé d’affaires on the 24th. of November. The Morning Chronicle takes it from the New York Commercial Advertiser of 26. December— The ratification is of the 22d. and published the next day in the National Intelligencer.— This was the day appointed here for the general Thanksgiving, for the termination of the War with France. All I heard of it was the ringing of the morning Bells for Church, and the chiming of the Bells at Brentford, as I returned from my walk round by Gunnersbury— After dinner I heard the boys read English Poetry.— Mrs More’s Moses, and Pope’s Messiah.

19. V:15. I finished this morning the Note to Lord Castlereagh upon the Fisheries, and wrote a Letter to Messrs: W and J Willink, at Amsterdam— I went into town, and took George with me. At the Office I found the package forwarded by Mr Maury from Liverpool, it enclosed three despatches from the Secretary of State. One containing the printed Report of the Secretary of the Treasury to Congress on the finances, and some other printed documents— One with duplicates of the despatches, dated 16. 19. and 20. November, and one a new despatch of 10. December, one half of which being in cypher I could not immediately read— I gave Mr Smith my Note on the fisheries to be copied out fair, and when ready, sent out to me for signature; and leaving George at the Office I walked down to 21. Austin Friars, Minet and Stride, with Mr Ludlow’s Bill of Exchange— The Clerks at the counting house told me, that I must leave the Bill and call again for it to-morrow; I told them I could not call to-morrow; that I lived ten miles out of town— They said it was the custom; I said there was no such custom by the Law of England— One of them said he would accept it as a favour, but it was not the usage— I told him I asked no favours—nothing but my right— If the Bill was not accepted I should protest it— He asked me if I was the person to whom the Bill was payable— I told him I was— He said, I was a very rude man— I came at improper hours (It was between three and four O’Clock.) They had hundreds of such Bills presented, every day. I told him I cared not how many Bills they had presented to them. I had but one, and if they did not accept it I would protest it— I offered to leave the Bill if they would send it to me to-morrow— He pettishly refused to send it to me— I repeated that I would protest the Bill— He threw it back to me and said you can’t protest it. Then he called the boy, and said recollect now what I say— The Bill is a good Bill— I took the Bill and came away. But I knew not where to find a Notary; and the Clock struck four, before I found the Consul’s Office, which is at N. 11. Threadneedle Street— I there gave the Bill to Mr Grubb, asking him to present it again to-morrow Morning, and if not then accepted, to give it to a Notary, to be protested; and if accepted to send it out to me— He said it was the custom to leave Bills a day— I told him I would not in this case; and desired him to tell them I should inform their correspondent of their behaviour. It was uncivil, disobliging, and impertinent; but on reflection I cannot acquit myself of having been hasty and peremptory, when by mildness and complacency, I might have got the Bill accepted, and saved myself, all further trouble.— Mr Grubb spoke to me about young Cleland, and said they were raising a Subscription to endeavour to get him released— I told him I had written to Mr Maury, in his behalf and was expecting his answer— I sat a few minutes with Mr Aspinwall, who told me that his vessel with the Seamen was not yet cleared at the Custom house— That instead of 120. he expected there would be 140 of the men &c— He apologized, for not having been out with Mrs: Aspinwall to visit us in the Country— I walked back to Craven Street; and found Mr Chrystie there— He proposes going to-morrow to Brighton, there to embark for France. I found also a Note from Prince Esterhazy, the Austrian Ambassador, acknowledging the receipt of mine, with the Letter for the Grand-Duke of Tuscany, which he promises to forward to its high destination— It was about five O’Clock when we left the Office, and near half past six when we reached home— I was engaged after dinner in reading Mr Dallas’s financial Report. And received at dinner the expected Letter from Mr Maury— But it does not contain the information that I had requested— It says Cleland will be released, if £60. can be raised for him.

20. VI: I was engaged until nearly Breakfast time in decyphering the despatch from the Secretary of State of 10. December—which gives me great occasion for reflection and anxiety— Much of the Morning after Breakfast was idled away, I know not how. I answered a Note, received last week from Count Beroldingen, the Minister of Wurtemberg, and began an answer to that from Baron Jacobi-Kloest the Prussian Minister, relating to Czeÿka’s Estate— Finished reading the Report of the Secretary of the Treasury on the Finances— Walked to the Turnpike on the Windsor Road. After dinner I attempted to read in Mr Hamilton’s Book, on the National debt of Great-Britain; but found that my eyes will not endure reading by the Evening Candle-light. While at dinner I received Letters from Mr Maury and Mr Hammett the Consuls at Liverpool and at Naples.

21. III:30. We have a small French Clock in our Bed-chamber, and I have lately risen as it struck 5 half past 5 or six. But it goes too fast, and has been for some days nearly an hour in advance. It has sometimes deceived me, by waking me as it struck five— The first stroke waking me, though I am not conscious of hearing it; and the counting the succeeding strokes suppose it only four O’Clock, until after lying an hour awake, I hear it strike six— It has now also got out of order, and strikes the hour, at the preceding half hour— It waked me this Morning as it struck five; but in counting the strokes I numbered them six— I rose, and went into George’s chamber, where Antoine sleeps, to light my Candle— Antoine after looking at his watch, came in to my washing chamber, and asked me if I meant to have the fire made in my writing-room then— I answered yes— He said it was not four O’Clock— I returned to our bed-chamber, and found the hand of the Clock at 20 minutes before five— It had Struck five at the half hour, which I had taken for six; and the hand being near an hour before the time, I had really risen at half past three. I told Antoine nevertheless to make the fire, and then go to bed again himself; which he did— I found no difficulty in employing the Morning until breakfast in writing to the Secretary of State— Went to Church with John and Charles. Prayers for the third Sunday after the Epiphany, were read by Mr Carr, and a Sermon preached by Mr: Millman, from John XI.43.44. [“]And when he thus had spoken, he cried with a loud voice, Lazarus, come forth. And he that was dead came forth, bound hand and foot with grave clothes: and his face was bound about with a napkin. Jesus saith unto them, Loose him, and let him go.” Mr Millman’s discourses are not dull; for they are short and fanciful. He was more at his ease, than last Sunday, which was his first performance— This day, the weather and walking being bad the attendance at Church was very thin.— I went out to take my usual walk before dinner, but was soon driven back by the rain. George resumed his reading in the French Bible at 1. Chronicles. Chap 5. after a suspension of 21 days— I made a very short Evening.

22. V: Wrote a Letter to my Brother, and enclosed to him F. Pursh’s second and third Notes, and an Order upon B. Austin Commissioner of Loans at Boston, to deliver to him the certificates, and pay him the dividends, on the Stock, standing in my name on the Boston Books— Received by the Postman at Noon, a packet from Mr J. A. Smith, enclosing a fair copy of the fishery. Note to Lord Castlereagh, which I examined, dated and signed— A cover from the Department of State with the President’s Message at the opening of the Session of Congress—in a National Intelligencer Extra of 5. December. A Letter from Mr Grubb, dated Saturday Morning, half past eleven, enclosing Mr Ludlow’s Bill on Minet and Stride, accepted, as of the 19th. the day when I presented it— And a Letter from Mr Harris at St: Petersburg, enclosing copies of the proceedings of the Imperial Council, relative to the Steam-Boat Privilege of the late Mr Fulton— Mrs Adams made a copy of my Letter to the Secretary of State— I wrote a short Letter to Mr S. Williams Finsbury Square— In the Evening the boys read part of Shakespear’s Midsummer Night’s Dream, and I was busied in making up packets for America.

23. V:30. After journalizing this Morning, I gave the remnant of time until breakfast, to the assortment of papers; an occupation upon which I employ or waste many hours. I went into London, and took my three Sons with me.— Called at Lord Castlereagh’s house, St James’s Street, Corner of the Square, and left the Note upon the Fisheries— Thence went to the Office in Craven Street. Found there a letter from a Mr Benedict, a merchant at Bristol, proposing to send to the U.S. three distressed American Seamen, in a Vessell which he is sending, full manned; if I would furnish him with a document upon which he could receive in America, the remuneration allowed by the Public for such Service. I gave Mr Smith the Letter, to take to Coll: Aspinwall, and request him to take the proper measures, to ascertain the facts, and if he thought proper, to send the men home; it being altogether within his Department. There was another application from an Englishman named Duffrell, addressed to the American Consul, and asking for assistance; because he had been living at Philadelphia; and during the late War his house had been mob’d and he, obliged to remove to Lancaster; from whence he escaped to New-York and returned to England— I desired Mr Smith, if the man should come again to dismiss him at once— Then came a man named Ashby, pretending to be a native of Boston, and wanting a Passport to go to America— He brought a Letter from a man of whom I knew nothing, certifying him to be a native American; but he spoke altogether with the English accent, and knew nothing of any body or any thing in Boston— I told him he must produce me some further Evidence of his being an American before I could give him a Passport— He went away, saying he thought he could bring more.
Mr John Watts came for a Passport to go to France; and he introduced to me his brother who came with him. Mr John Watts was formerly for some years the Publisher of the Port-Folio, at Philadelphia. In the Month of March 1807. I accidentally travelled in company with him, from Philadelphia to New-York, and had not seen him since— I did not recollect him, on his first coming in, but did immediately upon his mentioning his name— He is now establishing the Stereotype printing, according to Lord Stanhope’s invention, upon a large scale at New-York; and is going to France upon that business. His brother who has heretofore been Printer to the University of Cambridge, is now establishing the Stereotype printing in London—Picket Street, near Temple Bar— In about two months he expects to have his works complete, and promised me he would then shew them to me— Mr John Watts is to return here, from France, and to go out the next Fall to America— The father of Zerah Colburn, the innate Arithmetician from Vermont came to ask for money to bring him over here from France— He is now at the Polytechnic School, but Alderman Bridges, and Mr Crombie, and I know not who, have perswaded the father that he must bring him over here, and raise a subscription of £300 Sterling a year, for six years to educate the boy until 17. and to maintain the father here in the meantime. So the father has written to him to come over, and has received for answer, that he, cannot come, until his first suit of Clothes made for him as a scholar at the Polytechnic school have been paid for— And for this purpose Colburn the father wants five hundred franks— I told him that I saw no sufficient reason for bringing the boy here. He, the father had been extremely anxious to obtain admission for him at the Polytechnic school; when I saw him at Paris last Spring— I had then highly approved of that arrangement and saw no prospect either of advantage to the boy or of benefit to the public by taking him away and bringing him here. I did not believe he would obtain a subscription of £300 a year for six years, nor of half the money; and if he brought him here, under such an expectation he would only be disappointed, and lose the opportunity for his son’s education which he now enjoyed. He said he was not at all concerned about that, for alderman Bridges had told him he would subscribe five guineas a year himself and had promised to get as many as twenty more subscribers— Mr Crombie would get eight or ten, and so forth— I told him he would find he was leaning upon a broken reed, if he relied upon such promises— And at any rate I could not help him to the money he wanted If a subscription of £300 a year, for six years, could so easily be raised to educate his son and maintain himself there could be no difficulty in raising £20. to bring him here— I could neither approve nor lend my hand for any part of the expedient— He left me, complaining that since he had discovered his son’s mind; it had been nothing to him but a source of constant misfortunes— But the reason of that is that instead of availing himself of the liberality and benevolence of those who have contributed for the education of the boy; he has been, and is yet endeavouring to make it the means of raising money for his own support or emolument— And for that purpose has practiced delusion upon the public—particularly by the pretence of publishing a book, which is to contain the secret of his Son’s process of calculation.— These visitors engaged me until four O’Clock— I left with Mr Smith the despatches and Letters for America; to be taken this Evening to the New-England Coffee-house, and go thence in a bag to Liverpool— The weather and roads were so bad that I did not walk any part of the way home— We reached home about six— After dinner, the boys finished reading the Mid summer Night’s dream.

24. V:30. Excepting two short Letters; one to Mr Grubb, and the other to Mr William Cutting at New-York, Mr Fulton’s Executor, I accomplished nothing this day— Yet I was not conscious of being idle—I seemed to myself to be busily occupied, the whole day. Mrs: Adams went and paid several visits— The boys rode out with her— I walked to the ninth Milestone on the Windsor Road— Make minutes of the heads of conversation, with Lord Castlereagh— While at dinner I received Letters from Mr Maury, Mr Grubb, and Mr S. Williams.— After dinner I read with Charles an Act of Shakespear’s Mid summer Night’s dream.

25. V: I gave up this morning to the business of the day, and having a variety of Subjects upon which I wished to confer with Lord Castlereagh, I made a minute of the principal points to be borne in mind—classing them under ten different heads; and to preserve the order of them, arranged them alphabetically— Fixing upon a word which would immediately remind me of the whole subject— The initials of the word proceeding successively from A. to J— This was an application of the Principles of a technical memory which I had never made before, and which for a first attempt succeeded, not completely; but beyond my expectation— I have often experienced inconvenience in conferences of this kind, by forgetting while engaged in the conversation upon some of the topics, for which I had proposed the interview, others perhaps of equal importance; or at least observations that before the meeting, I had intended to make, and which after the meeting I regretted to have omitted. I did not entirely escape the second of these maladdresses, but had less of it than I have often experienced; and none of the principal topics were omitted— In one instance the order of my arrangement was discomposed, much to my own satisfaction; for as it was a Subject upon which my instructions were to feel the pulse of this Government without committing my own, I was under some embarrassment how to introduce it— But it had an incidental connection with another Subject which I had classed in order before it, and as
I was to disclose explicitly my Instructions on the first point (Florida) and to speak entirely from myself on the other (South America) I had separated them with an interval of two others between them— But in the midst of our discussion of the former, Lord Castlereagh himself introduced the latter, and more than compensated for the inroad upon my arrangement, by relieving me from the aukwardness of entering upon most delicate and difficult matter upon which I was to treat. I did not lose by this incident the clue of my alphabetical arrangement, which though in appearance whimsical, I found decidedly useful— I went into town immediately after breakfast, and was at Lord Castlereagh’s door at half past eleven—the hour that he had appointed for the meeting— I sent away the Carriage, with orders to come for me to Craven Street at four— I was detained, not five minutes in the Antichamber, where I saw a young man, I suppose a private Secretary but not Planta. Lord Castlereagh immediately received me in his Library— He began upon the dampness and foulness of the weather— Then enquired whether I resided in town— Said Lady Castlereagh had made enquiries for Mrs: Adams, but was informed we were still in the Country.— I enquired if he had any Accounts this morning from the Prince Regent, who is laid up at Brighton, with the Gout— He said the Prince was now free from Pain and recovering— But it had become at last after shifting about for several days, a regular attack; and as it had left him weak, his medical attendants had advised that Parliament, which is to sit on the first of February, should be opened by Commission, and that the Prince should remain ten days or a fortnight longer at Brighton, before coming to Town.— He said the Prince had exposed himself to the damp weather in going round with him, to shew him the place; (the new Pavilion at Brighton) and afterwards to the Queen, when she came. The Gout had been some days unsettled; but had finally fixed, and the attack while it lasted had been sharp— We now entered upon the subjects for which I had requested the interview, and I shall give the dialogue to the best of my recollection as it passed; distinguishing the speakers respectively by the initials of their names— A. I have observed by the Public papers that your Lordship has received the Ratification by the President of the United States, of the Commercial Convention concluded in July last— C. Yes—and the Ratifications may be exchanged in a few days . . . or . . . I believe they were exchanged there; at Washington. . . A. That was what I wished to enquire of your Lordship—having myself no advices from my Government, since the Ratification— C.—Yes—the Ratifications were exchanged there— A. At the time when that Convention was concluded, the Full-Powers of the American Plenipotentiaries were much more extensive than the objects upon which it was found the parties could then come to an agreement; and as my two Colleagues were shortened for time, and anxious to return to America; it was thought best to conclude what we could then adjust, and notice was given by us, that further proposals might afterwards be brought forward by me—for negotiation.— The British Plenipotentiaries told us that their powers would be terminated by the Convention then signed; and in case of a further Negotiation they did not know whether it would be committed to them. I then informed them, that I should not propose any thing further, without new Instructions from my Government, and in that case, should address myself through the regular channel of the Foreign Department— Since then I have received Instructions directing me to make proposals for arrangements which I presumed could be settled only in the form of a Treaty— Other proposals of negotiation had been made, in the course of my Correspondence here, during your Lordships absence in France, by Lord Bathurst; I wished therefore now to enquire, what are the Views of His Majesty’s Government in this respect— Whether they are disposed to enter upon a new Negotiation—and if they are whether they will consider the Full Power heretofore produced by my Colleagues and me as competent for concluding an additional Treaty; or will they expect me to produce a new Power— And whether I shall treat with the same British Plenipotentiaries with whom we treated before; or with your Lordship— C.
